Eric’s message on some other thread pointed me to the field_simp tactic, which I didn’t know yet, and which I could have used in a proof a few days ago. But playing around with it I notice that it is rather naive about the non-zeroness of denominators, e.g. a hypothesis x > 0 is not enough.

I naively would have expected that field_simp would use the positivity tactic for the side-conditions, which is quite good at proving that things are not zero. Is there a reason why it doesn't work this way?
Thanks! Should have searched for this first.
Joachim Breitner has marked this topic as resolved.
There is also #6034 which addresses the additional issue but with casts. I didn’t know about #4835 when doing this so I need to take a look!
I’m giving it a shot at https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6312, at least as a learning experience, potentially as a useful contribution.
Ok, I have fixed the fallout throughout mathlib, and did some golfing to show that this is a useful idea, so happy to receive some feedback on the PR now (not urgent, of course)
Oh that is an awesome diff! Congratulations!
